{"comments": {"id": 27523, "count": 22, "talk_id": 3614}, "threadId": 27523, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "3614", "description": "With warmth and grace, Beth Malone tells the deeply personal story of her dad's struggle with frontotemporal lobe dementia, and how it changed how she thinks about death (and life). A moving talk about a daughter's love -- and of letting go and finding peace.", "event": "TED Residency", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Beth Malone: How my dad's dementia changed my idea of death (and life)", "slug": "beth_malone_how_my_dad_s_dementia_changed_my_idea_of_death_and_life", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3470", "slug": "beth_malone", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Beth", "lastname": "Malone", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Social entrepreneur, artist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/b2690f8fdb99cd2fe608743709e075693266eae2_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "TED Resident Beth Malone brings bold art to public spaces across the US, encouraging artists to have a sense of humor, to be vulnerable and take creative risks.", "whylisten": "

Beth Malone is executive director and partner at Dashboard US, an award-winning, experimental creative agency. Dashboard has presented exhibitions and special artist projects in cities around the country including New York, New Orleans, Atlanta, and Detroit. Dashboard has commissioned new, nontraditional works from over 200 artists.

Malone encourages artists to have a sense of humor, to be vulnerable and take creative risks, a practice she employed for herself when processing illness, caretaking and death. In 2014, she and her dad were sitting on a couch in a psychiatric hospital in Atlanta, GA. He looked at her and said, "I’m gonna be lost after this. After this, I’m gonna be gone." In August 2017, her dad passed away from frontotemporal lobe dementia -- just two months after she gave her TED Talk. It was a good death.

"}], "url": "https://www.ted.com/talks/beth_malone_how_my_dad_s_dementia_changed_my_idea_of_death_and_life", "viewed_count": 1220074, "talks": [{"recommendations": {"status": "approved", "headline": "Beth Malone recommends", "blurb": "Check out these additional resources, curated by Beth Malone", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": "", "type": "recommendation", "rec_lists": [{"title": "", "description": "", "rec_items": [{"label": "EXPLORE", "headline": "COSMS", "blurb": "In early 2014, dad started falling fast into dementia. I had no comprehension of how to deal with the grief. So I did what most people do, I got outta bed every day and went to work. Dashboard, my company, was in the middle of producing a mass art exhibition called COSMS. We’d commissioned 12 artists from Atlanta, New York and New Orleans to make large-scale installations inspired by light. [COSMS](http://www.dashboard.us/cosms) was presented on the cavernous fourth floor of an Atlanta highrise. Some of the works were abstract glowing other-worlds, and some tapped into the human experience and memory. Artist Dustin Chambers actually created an immersive maze that simulated effects of Alzheimer’s. It paid homage to his grandmother who suffered from the disease and resonated deeply with audiences. For months during the exhibition’s run, I would escape into this and the other 11 artworks — they healed me beyond measure. COSMS was also the last Dashboard show my dad was able to visit. ", "note": "", "link_url": "http://www.dashboard.us/cosms", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "EXPLORE", "headline": "Tori Tinsley's Hugs Series", "blurb": "Artist Tori Tinsley makes paintings about the loss of her mother to frontotemporal lobe dementia (FTD). The series Hugs is gorgeous, grotesque, poignant, and full of humility. ", "note": "", "link_url": "http://www.toritinsley.com/hugs/", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "EXPLORE", "headline": "My art", "blurb": "I make neon sculpture and installations. I like using my hands to make electrical connections between discarded neon shapes in hopes that when I flip a switch something pretty will happen. Sometimes nothing happens. A mis-wire. A lot of this work has become a literal representation of dad’s brain for me. ", "note": "", "link_url": "http://bethannemalone.com", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "LISTEN", "headline": ""Terrible, Thanks for Asking"", "blurb": "Terrible, Thanks for Asking has helped me come to terms with terminal illness, caregiving, and most recently, the death of my dad. Nora McInerney’s podcast is a vulnerable, funny exploration of grief and loss. [This](https://www.apmpodcasts.org/ttfa/2017/01/8-the-middle-place/) is my favorite episode.", "note": "", "link_url": "https://www.apmpodcasts.org/ttfa/", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "WATCH", "headline": "*Alive Inside*", "blurb": "*Alive Inside* is a tearjerker, y’all, but honestly, music always proved to be the best medicine for dad. This film helped me understand why. ", "note": "", "link_url": "http://www.aliveinside.us/#land", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Forget Memory*", "blurb": "I was so afraid of dad losing his memories. Who would he be without them? But then a brilliant, very dear friend gave me this book and I learned strategies to shift my thinking. ", "note": "Anne Davis Basting ", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Forget-Memory-Creating-Better-Dementia/dp/0801892503/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": "Readings on assisted suicide", "blurb": "I have thought a lot about assisted suicide. These things answered some of my questions and spurred new ones: ["The Death Treatment: When should people with a non-terminal illness be helped to die?"](https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/06/22/the-death-treatment) Rachel Aviv, *The New Yorker*, 2015. ["My Right to Die: Assisted suicide, my family, and me."](http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/01/assisted-suicide-legalization-california-kevin-drum/) Kevin Drum, *Mother Jones*, 2017. ["Episode #11: The Ending Matters."](https://www.apmpodcasts.org/ttfa/2017/09/the-ending-matters/) Nora McInerney, "Terrible, Thanks for Asking," 2017", "note": "", "link_url": "", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "EXPLORE", "headline": "Fountainview Center for Alzheimer’s Disease ", "blurb": "Facilities that specialize in Alzheimer's or other forms of dementia are rare, and, due to overwhelming need, they’re hard to get your loved one into (especially if they smoke two packs of menthol cigarettes a day). The team at Fountainview not only helped my family by caring for -- and loving -- our wily dad for three years, they also helped us navigate the very confusing elder care system. If you are looking for help finding a place for your loved one, these folks may be able to point you to a facility in your area. ", "note": "", "link_url": "http://www.thefountainviewcenter.com/", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "EXPLORE", "headline": "Penn FTD Center", "blurb": "The good people at Penn FTD Center are doing serious work. Everything you need to know about FTD from language to caregiving to science can be found on their website. They update it regularly to reflect the rapidly changing research around FTD.", "note": "", "link_url": "https://ftd.med.upenn.edu/", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}]}, "more_resources": [{"status": "approved", "headline": "TED Residency", "blurb": "The TED Residency is an incubator for breakthrough ideas. It's free and open to all via a semiannual competitive application. "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Social entrepreneur, artist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/b2690f8fdb99cd2fe608743709e075693266eae2_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "TED Resident Beth Malone brings bold art to public spaces across the US, encouraging artists to have a sense of humor, to be vulnerable and take creative risks.", "whylisten": "

Beth Malone is executive director and partner at Dashboard US, an award-winning, experimental creative agency. Dashboard has presented exhibitions and special artist projects in cities around the country including New York, New Orleans, Atlanta, and Detroit. Dashboard has commissioned new, nontraditional works from over 200 artists.

Malone encourages artists to have a sense of humor, to be vulnerable and take creative risks, a practice she employed for herself when processing illness, caretaking and death. In 2014, she and her dad were sitting on a couch in a psychiatric hospital in Atlanta, GA. He looked at her and said, "I’m gonna be lost after this. After this, I’m gonna be gone." In August 2017, her dad passed away from frontotemporal lobe dementia -- just two months after she gave her TED Talk. It was a good death.

"}], "speaker_name": "Beth Malone", "tags": ["death", "disease", "humanity", "family", "illness", "mental health", "life", "TED Residency", "personal growth"], "title": "How my dad's dementia changed my idea of death (and life)", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1220074}]}
